stimulusHtml:
In your response you should do the following.

  • Respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning.
  • Describe a broader historical context relevant to the prompt.
  • Support an argument in response to the prompt using at least four documents.
  • Use at least one additional piece of specific historical evidence (beyond that found in the documents) relevant to an argument about the prompt.
  • For at least two documents, explain how or why the document’s point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience is relevant to an argument.
  • Demonstrate a complex understanding of a historical development related to the prompt through sophisticated argumentation and/or effective use of evidence.  

Evaluate whether resistance to Napoleon Bonaparte throughout Europe was motivated primarily by Europeans’ emerging nationalism or primarily by attachment to existing institutions.

features.html:
Directions: This question is based on the seven accompanying documents. The documents have been edited for the purpose of this exercise.

 

Document 1

Source: “A Patriotic Song,” the Aberdeen Journal, Scotland, ca. 1805

Come all ye gallant Scottish swains [young men],

From town and cottage, hills and plains,

Let every village beat to arms,

And join the warlike quorum [assembly].

 

For Bonaparte he’ll be here,

Bonaparte, Bonaparte,

For Bonaparte he’ll be here,

The great devil choke him.

 

For Bonaparte he’ll be here,

He will not leave us horse or mare,

He’ll take our other going gear,

And drive them all before him.

 

But let us true and faithful stand,

Heart to heart, and hand to hand,

When the rascals try to land,

We shall be there before ’em.

 

Why does this corrupt usurper boast,

That he’ll invade our British coast,

We’ll show him Soldiers to his cost,

Was born long before him.

 

He’ll find our courage still the same,

We’ll turn his glory to his shame,

Our old Claymore [sword] we’ll try again,

And highland blood devour him.

Document 2

Source: Letter from Pope Pius VII to Napoleon, 1806

Your Majesty lays down the principle that you are the Emperor of Rome. I reply, with apostolic frankness, that the Pope, who became Sovereign of Rome so many centuries ago that no other sovereignty on earth can go back to a more remote point in history, does not acknowledge, and never has acknowledged, any power superior to himself in his own dominions. Your Majesty is immensely great; you have been elected, crowned, consecrated, and acknowledged, as Emperor of the French, but not as Emperor of Rome.

Document 3

Source: Letter from Napoleon to the Emperor of Austria, October 1808

Sire, my Brother:

I had it in my power to dismember your Majesty’s monarchy, or at least to diminish its power. I did not do so. It exists as it is by my consent. This is a plain proof that our accounts are settled; that I have no desire to injure you. I am always ready to guarantee the integrity of your monarchy. I will never do anything adverse to the important interests of States. But your Majesty ought not to bring again under discussion what has been settled by a fifteen years’ war. You ought to avoid every proclamation or act calculated to lead to war.

Document 4

Source: Anonymous Russian nun, account of the French occupation of Moscow, 1812

They slept in the sanctuary, they ate off the altar. In the hospital church there was a large icon representing the appearances of the Mother of God, painted on wood and without fittings. One of our elderly sisters had bought it with her own money and presented it to the church. The French took it from the wall and used it as a table. We were extremely upset to find that they had no respect for our churches, and our chaplain said to us: “How do you expect them to revere churches which have been turned into dwelling-places. If they sin through ignorance, God will forgive them, because they have not profaned any holy relics.”

Document 5

Source: Twelve princesses of the House of Hohenzollern, led by princess Marianne of Prussia, “Appeal to the Women of the Prussian State,” March 1813

We women, too, must participate, and must help promote victory. We, too, must unite with the men and boys to save our fatherland. Thus let us found an association with the name of Women’s Association for the Good of the Fatherland.

This association will accept as donations not merely cash money, but any valuable spare trinket . . . Monthly contributions, material, linen cloth, spun wool and yarn will be gladly accepted, and even the working of these raw materials without pay will be regarded as an offering. These offerings serve to arm, clothe and equip the defenders who need it, and if the rich benevolence of women puts us in a position to do yet more, then the wounded will also be nursed, healed and returned to the grateful fatherland.

Document 6

Source: Dutch cartoon, “Napoleon in the Press,” printed during the allied campaign against Napoleon after his 1812 defeat in Russia, 1813

 
 

Soldiers of the Allied nations squeeze Napoleon in a press, as the names of various liberated countries, including Holland, spill from his mouth.

Document 7

Source: Memorandum by the Piedmontese ambassador, Count Cotti di Brusasco, to the Tsar Alexander, March 1818

By one of those despotic caprices with which he appeared to delight in affronting accepted notions and doing violence to nature, Bonaparte had decided to make several millions of Italians into Frenchmen—first the Piedmontese*, then the Genoese*, then the Tuscans* and finally the Romans*. An artificial line now separated the populations who were intended by their topographical position, by their language and common origins, by nature itself, to form a single nation. Bonaparte imagined he could level the Alps, or rather transport them to his arbitrary line . . . by simple decree. The whole of French Italy was peopled with French employees, from the chief officer of police to the lowliest tax collector.

*Inhabitants of various regions of northern and central Italy
